ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn Hoyle
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jennifer Hoyle
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn Hoyle
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn!
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jennifer Hoyle
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn, clearly.
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn Hoyle
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jennifer Hoyle

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn is very responsive to students needs, helpful with final projects, and when she is not able to be in class, she does her best to be present online to help us! She is awesome.

Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Extensive knowledge and useful experience on the subject matter. Working on her own PhD research at times made her (understandably) less available that would be desired. Oh well. She was great when she was available. No complaints.
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn was a great teaching assistant. Very helpful, clear, committed to student learning, and fair.
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn asked Jim lots of really useful/helpful questions and helped directed the conversation when needed.
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn is great!

Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Very flexible and responsive. Jenn was very willing to re-schedule field trips. She is incredibly knowledgeable of the course material and generous with her time.

Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn is an approachable and helpful TA who tries her best to provide assistance in the different assignments throughout the course. She is able to ask pertinent questions in class to shed light on issues and concerns tied to river restoration as she had the experience of working out in the field. These questions would not be asked by the class as most of us do not have the insight to the actual construction works. Her questions had helped to clarify and provide depth to the discussion. She is one of the best TA I have worked with! Great work Jenn!

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Jim is a great instructor - it was wonderful to learn from a current practitioner how to evaluate and restore rivers. I learned a lot from him. He was also so helpful with the final projects, and went out over various weekends to help groups complete their projects, always with a smile on his face and a snack for us! I am very glad he decided to teach the class this year. Thanks Jim!

Jim has an intimate understanding how how rivers work and his enthusiasm for the subject material shows through. His wealth of real world experience and theoretical understanding is a real asset to all students interested in river processes and/or restoration or watershed management work.
Jim knows so much about the topic it was always interesting to hear him lecture. It would have been good to get more foundational information in addition to the case studies we learned.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The field trips were a highlight. Jim is a practitioner, and it was helpful to see him in his element. We visited a number of sites that he and his company is involved in. The trips are necessary to better understand how river restoration really works. Jim's tangents on his past projects were also enjoyable, and he goes on a lot of tangents...
Field trips and real application of what we learned in class.

In field experience. Going out to the rivers and seeing things first hand. The rest of the classes is a flood of powerpoint, charts, pictures, etc. but nothing beats putting your boots on and getting out into the rivers.
Field trips!
Jim's wealth of knowledge and learning from him and Jenn in the field.

Learning from Jim was a great experience. He was so helpful on our final project, and I felt I was absorbing some of the knowledge he has gained throughout his long career. Working on a project helped me to see how a similar project could work in a "real world" consulting situation. The field trips were fun as well.
Jim is very knowledgeable and great. The field trips were the best part so we could see what we talked about in class

The professional experience of our lecturer and the field trips were helpful ways to consolidate the lectures. The field trips provide the grounding for the theoretical discussion in class by demonstrating its application. This is something important for a professional school as it prepares students for work upon graduation.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The course this semester was a bit disjointed. Part of that is because the structure of the course was altered for this semester to fit Jim's schedule, but I think better care could have been taken to present the material in a more straight forward manner. More applied practice and activities for the students to take part in would have been helpful.
The long field trip write up and the final take home exam seemed repetitive. Also since we completed a final project, the final exam felt like unnecessary busy work.
I wish the class was more applied and discussion based.
Would like more foundational information in Lecture.
Following through on the idea of student-led paper discussions would have been great. We had a few presentations, but there was little back and forth discussion at the end of them.
The course wasn't very well organized--there wasn't a good flow from week to week. The readings were erratic and not that helpful. Expectations were vague.

I felt that the number of assignments for the class should be listed out clearly at the start of the semester so that students could plan for the work that is required. For instance, I did not expect a report for each of our field trip and one of them were of consideration length. However, I see the value in the report as I learnt alot from them.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes. I wish we had more opportunity to go out in the field to look at projects.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I will now look at streams differently!
This course should be essential for anyone who considers themselves a freshwater person.
Very interested in water resource management. Would like to do this sort of work in the future.
Physical science requirement for MF degree.

As an urban planner, understanding how the urban environment affects hydrology is an important aspect of environmental planning. As many cities around the world engaged in river restoration/rehabilitation work, the knowledge would be helpful to provide basic understanding of the process going into river restoration and key factors to take into consideration. It also provides the language to speak with engineers and hydrologist.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am interested in water resources generally.

I have an appreciation for rivers that has increased dramatically as a result of the things I learned in this course. Understanding the mechanics and the processes that make up a river system makes seeing rivers in nature a whole new experience.
To learn about how to classify rivers and learn the language of river restoration folks.
I wanted to learn what a firm like Milone and MacBroom did, and I got a nice overview!
To fulfill MF requirements. Also wanted to learn about fluvial morphology as it relates to forests.
See above

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Needs more field work and perhaps more work at the watershed level, not just in river visits and slide shows.
Yes - but again, wish it was more applied.
Would have liked more foundational knoledge.
For the most part, yes. There wasn't too much discussion of hydrology/modeling, so I might have wanted a bit more of that.
Not entirely. I was hoping for a bit more policy as well as watershed aspects.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: My team worked really well together.
Work for the group project was great.
I had a great experience with my group. I felt like we all had different strengths, and we complimented one another nicely.
Advantage - able to discuss issues and share ideas Disadvantage - scheduling of time

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Taught in the seminar form there was ample time for questions and discussions. You could either skate by, enjoy the show each week, or do some of the technical readings and get Jim's take an any variety of river issues. The workload is generally light, a few papers and plans involving "what would you do" to restore this river. Also, a group project where you get to do a "restoration" or any river-related project near the end of the term.
Take it! Jim is super knowledgeable. Just keep asking him questions!
Do it, ask lots of questions. Go on all the field trips.

This is an awesome class with a pair of good lecturer and TA. Worth the time and effort if you intend to work on river restoration projects in the future or just a good skill to add on to your resume.
